description:
This review is only for the beer. $12 for a half pint may seem steep and we almost walked by because of the price. I had heard this place was a BFD to come stateside, though, so we decided to get one round just to try it. This place was pretty empty on a Saturday night around 8PM which is surprising.

We were sat at a table in the bar area and could not decide what beers to order based on their short list. We asked our server for some help and she recommend the Red Rice Ale ($10) and the Yuzu Lager ($12) so we got one of each to share. Let me just say, both of these beers were unique and delicious. I definitely preferred the Yuzu Lager since it was lighter and the flavor was more subtle than the strong Red Rice Ale but would not hesitate to drink either again. The price for these beers is worth it, even if only once in a while. They were so unique and delicious.

I have to say, even though we came in for drinks we got to see the food coming out of the kitchen and it both looked and smelled fantastic. I want to come back and eat here, even if it will be an expensive meal.
author: Carrie W.

description:
Good food. Nice service. Tasty beer. 
I love this place. I would come again. 
Don't come if you think wagyu is not worth $$$.
author: Agatha L.

description:
Delicious! Yes, it's a bit expensive, especially if you're ordering the tasting menu, but if you're looking for steak, you should expect that price.  

To start, we split the Wagyu burger-- they only serve 5 per night!  They were kind enough to cut it in half for us, which worked out well because of its size (it's a pretty big burger.) We really wanted the katsu sandwich but couldn't justify spending $125, despite our desire to find a great katsu sandwich outside of Japan.

For mains, I ordered the Wagyu donburi and my boyfriend ordered the steak.  Both were amazing!

In addition to the great food, the service was spectacular.

We'll be back!
author: Grace P.

description:
Stay for the beer, exit immediately if hungry. 

It's so infrequent to have a "bad" meal in this town but, in a recent visit to Hitachino I experienced one of the worst displays of culinarily arts in my life. Yes, the food was that bad. 

Here's the problem. They are advertising Wagyu beef at Wagyu prices but, in the dishes that we ordered, it definitely wasn't Wagyu. The uni and Wagyu tempura might have been a London broil, the beef tongue skewer was unseasoned, gamey and a total mess. The other special skewers were rolled into balls of something that was indescribable. In fact, I had no idea what we were eating at that point. I legit took one bit of each thing we ordered and sent it all back. I've never done that in my life.  

Our server was super nice and understanding about the food that we sent back, so five stars to that dude. 

Overall...Hard pass.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
Yes, as the reviews indicate, it is expensive for the portion sizes here.  If you go in knowing this, you can still have a good meal.

The beer was great if course. Got the red rice ale. Friend got yuzu ale.  So. Yuzu.

Friend got wagyu gyoza which was nice and crispy.  Vinegar sauce complements well

Wife got tantan men which had such a deep umami flavor it tastes like liquid pizza

I got the wagyu rib donburi.  Buttery garlic rice delicious

Another friend got the small curry.  Also super tasty

Come for a splurge night
author: Marshall Y.

description:
Is at by myself at the bar and has the warmest welcome with the bartender. I had just eaten dinner so I wasn't in the mood for any more food but how could you resist here? The beef is fantastic.

Oh and did I mention this is the only Hitachino restaurant outside of Japan? With how pricy Hitachino is, I was so happy to see reasonable prices here. I've easily paid $12-15 for Hitachino elsewhere so even though it was still pricey I felt spoiled by the prices.

They had three sours on tap that I got through including a salty plum gose that was unlike any beer I've ever had. The bartender told me that it's not actually a gose by style but I definitely was fooled. So good.

For food I had the octopus sunomo, beef tongue and wagyu nigiri. They were all so good but the nigiri took the cake. So succulent and the glaze really brought it up to another level.

The bartender again was fantastic. I didn't catch him name but he was so educated in all the beers and food. You could tell he cared about his work and spent more time than I was expecting chatting me up. He also pointed me to some local haunts that I hit up afterwards.

I will miss this place when I head back to DC!
author: Brandon B.

description:
The beers are great, enough said.

I went with friends and we all had the tasting menu.  One person was vegetarian and they did a terrific tasting menu for her that was very innovative and tasty (something they don't tell you unless you ask for it).  We're picky eaters and all our dishes were excellent and you get the right amount of food (the curry was a bit of a miss for me, but the other dishes more than made up for it).  The nigiri and the sandwich were to die for.  The tempura banana with a dab of chocolate ganache for dessert was also very good.  We also had a few a la carte items that were very good.

Don't eat here if you're on a budget and think you're going to get wagyu on the cheap.  That ain't happening, stick to the beers and then eat elsewhere.  And I wouldn't recommend doing the a la carte.  The tasting menu has a great flow to it with good presentation, variety and flavors.  You're never going to get that experience from just one or two of the dishes.  And unless you're an expert on Japanese cuisine, picking out something by itself is likely to be more of a miss than a hit.  All of us agreed that we'd be back to do the tasting menu again in the future, which isn't cheap but is a good experience.
author: Holger B.

description:
I've had nothing but great experiences here. Our first time here was in November of 2017. We were big fans of Hitachino's nest beer already and decided to give this restaurant a try. 

The beers on tap were absolutely top notch, and even better than the bottled versions sold in stores.

My favorite is their Red Rice Ale. But they are also known for their fantastic sake as well. Our waiter gave us a taste and we were very impressed.

The time, attention, and intention put into their dishes is evident when you taste the food. We had the wagyu sushi as well as the bacon mochi. Delicious. We loved our experience so much, that we decided to come back for dinner again the next evening.

Fast forward to July 2018. We recently came back to try out their pop-up lunch menu. My husband had the wagyu curry and I had the wagyu ramen. Both were outstanding and impressive, given the $14 price point for a wagyu dish.

I'd absolutely go out of my way to experience their dinner and drinks. Love this place and will definitely be back again.
author: Mary S.

description:
Exceptional food and beer. We ordered the pre fixed menu everything was amazing except the meatball at the end. I swear there was no meat in it, all that great food and they ended the meal with the worst thing. I suggest just ordering al a cart. 
Deffienty they the beer best ever and great service
author: sarah s.

description: Hitachino beer stands head and shoulders above the rest and it's always best to get it from the source.  While there, sample the HitachiWagu steak.  Also ask about the seasonal beers like this Saison.
author: Darren K.

description:
I'm disappointed to leave such a bad review for this place, but not as disappointed as I was in the food here considering how good the menu sounded.

We've enjoyed Hitachino beer before and really love wagyu and Japanese dishes, so to see that they had opened a tap room of sorts in SF was exciting for us - and it is the only one in the US, which feels really special. At first...

It was a Friday evening at 6:30 and the restaurant was pretty empty, I'd say there were two other tables other than our own and a couple bar patrons. The door was left open and it was pretty drafty, but whatever. If a place has bad ventilation, I guess they have to do that, so fair enough.

First bad signs; they were out of two of the 10 or so Hitachino beers that they offer. One of the specials was a Hefeweizen, and that's what we ordered. Hefeweizen is one of my favorite styles of beer but this tasted so sour it might as well have been a gose. Really tangy and not in a way that suited this style. I was willing to accept that it might've been more suited to Japanese tastes and chalked it up to experience. Still, I was disappointed that the server said it had 'classic hefeweizen flavors' and it kinda didn't. It was also expensive, $10 for maybe about 10 oz. You'd pay less to get a bottle of Hitachino at a speciality liquor store. Again though, I was still excited because the menu seemed amazing.

We hemmed and hawed about what to order, and decided on a large curry and the donburi to split. First to arrive was the donburi, and the wagyu on top was (and I'm being generous) like pretty decent quality roast beef. Certainly nothing special. There were less than 10 slices, an admittedly well done soft boiled egg and oh...about 1/2 cup of rice. Rice is cheap - fill it up for $29, please.

Already kinda disappointed, but it got worse - my dining companion found either a hard piece of plastic or a piece of glass in his portion of the donburi. When the server came back we told him and he offered to take the donburi off the bill. All good there - can't fault the guy and the way it was handled, and if the food wasn't so awful I'd be giving an extra star just for this fact. I appreciated the quick and courteous service and the way the situation was dealt with. The situation shouldn't have happened (something hard and inedible in food is far worse than any little hair or anything, which I wouldn't even have complained about) but they took it off the bill no questions asked. We stopped eating it but the bowls were left on our table and felt kinda shameful, haha.

Then the curry arrived and it was subpar. Again, very little rice was given with this dish (and since we hadn't ate that donburi we were pretty hungry) and the curry itself was more soupy. It was almost like a spiced beef stew. I can't fault the spice profile on the curry - BUT, homemade curry straight from roux blocks is just as good. Any quick service curry in Japan will be tastier. The wagyu in the curry was okay, a bit fatty and kinda tough but at least it didn't contain any foreign particles.

We could tell that after we found the foreign object in our food that our server felt uncomfortable - honestly, it wasn't his fault and the service was fine. When the food is this bad, this meanly portioned and this expensive however, I can't give more than 2 stars. When that happens AND we find some random inedible object in the food, I can't give more than 1 star. Sorry Hitachino, not for me. I'll stick to the bottles.
author: Chelsea C.

description:
Came here for happy hour today with a couple of girlfriends. I'm a fan of Hitachino Beer in general, so it's owl-fully nice to have a taproom in the city ;)

HH special is $10 for 3 small pours of your choice. I think they were roughly 1/3 pint each. My favorite was Anbai with salt ume. The Saison du Japon was summery and pleasant with flavors from yuzu. Cherry Blossom and Red Rice ale was decent but not a standout for me.

The bar snacks were pretty good. We shared a pickle plate, which was basically just kimchi. Ordered the beef tendon stew with konyakku. The beef was super tender, though I think the broth could have been more seasoned. Chicken thigh and gizzard was probably the best. The chicken had a lovely grilled flavor, gizzard was soft, and the dashi was tasty. I may have drank it. I totally drank it.

Would definitely come back for happy hour beers!
author: Lydia C.

description:
My friends and I came here for my brother's birthday and we loved the immensely tasty flavors of the beef tongue skewers, wagyu nigiri and dumplings.  While the curry and rice offered probably the most value of the items, its flavors didn't stand out in much any way.

For libations, all the Hitachino drafts came at a hefty price tag yet they delivered across the board.  We all thoroughly enjoyed our picks ranging from the red ale to the red wine barrel aged sour that actually reminded me of Russian River Brewing's Consecration.

So why the 2 stars?  I was incorrectly charged extra on my credit card despite having the gratuity already included in the total amount given our party size.  I called and left a message to have the manager follow up with me, but I received no return call despite clearly stating that I would dispute the charge if I did not hear back in a timely manner.  I had to do just that and it was troublesome to say the least.
author: Eric F.

description:
First off... if you're not an enthusiastic meateater (and one that partakes in beef), you won't appreciate this place. So just don't come - you'll be setting yourself and the restaurant up for failure.

Also, if you're reading a lot of the 1-star reviews from last year, those are not an accurate representation of the restaurant as it is today (April 2018) since it opened without a full menu. As of this review, there was a full tasting menu along with a WAGYU-full a la carte menu with a variety of ways to partake in the yummeat. 

We decided to pass on the tasting menu, because there were a lot of fancy words that sounded like garnishes and edible flowers, and we already had our eyes on a few things that we knew would blow us away just as much as a beautifully plated, multi course option. 

Let's get to the meat. 

We got the Wagyu Bacon Mochi, the Skewer Set (with Wagyu Katsu / Wagyu Meatball / Beef Tongue / Mushroom that I can't remember), Wagyu Nigiri, Wagyu Donburi, Wagyu Curry & Rice (Large) and the kitchen surprised us with the dessert (melon in multiple ways). 

The Wagyu Nigiri was my favorite thing from the evening. The meat was soooo tender. The order comes with two pieces. We liked it so much we wanted to place another order for dessert but they started wiping down the kitchen and brought out complimentary dessert. 

The Skewer Set was also top. That Wagyu meatball literally crumbles in your mouth. So delicious. I wanted an entire loaf of it (can you guys do that, plz?). Katsu, Tongue and Mushroom were also tasty but outshined by that meatball. 

Donburi was the most generous meat-wise, with a perfectly poached egg and super garlicky (YUM) white rice underneath. Really nice. Would order again. My dining buddy is all about the curry & rice so we ordered the large portion, which was really indulgent (our waiter warned us). It was one of the richest Japanese curries I've had... the spices, the wagyu and the heat. So much so that we had to order a side of rice (they've got their rice down) so we could finish it... but we did because it was that good. 

The only thing that I would not order again was the Wagyu Bacon Mochi. It sounded really unique so we knew we wanted to try it however the rice paste was warm (maybe seared?) and therefore super sticky and much too much for the amount of meat that it came with. If I had put the whole thing in my mouth I might have choked because it was so adhesive to all parts of my mouth. 

I would instead slot in the Wagyu Tantanmen Ramen. We'll be back for that one. 

Dessert was nice (and not just 'cause it was free), but let's face it, we're here for the meat and not the dessert. I'd rather have Wagyu Nigiri to close out the meal than something sweet. 

Beer. For beer lovers I imagine that it's a treat to be able to pair some of these unique options with the wagyu. I enjoy beer but my beer palette is pretty simple and unsophisticated so we just ordered a few of Hitachino beers: the Yuzu Lager & the Japanese Classic Ale. Really tasty and unique flavors - really nice to have with our meat picks. That's as much as I can tell you on this front. 

Service was really chill and it seems like all of the guys genuinely enjoy working there which makes for a much nicer experience for everyone all around. 

Overall, I think the restaurant deserves a lot more love than it's getting and we for sure will be back in soon!
author: Sam P.

description:
The tasting was surprisingly varied and interesting. 

Enjoyed: 
-wines reasonably priced at $13
-everything has their owl logo emblazoned
-binchotan charcoal filtered water 
-excellent knowledgeable service 
-super tender beef tongue
-Japanese condiments and accompaniments 
-wagyu sushi 
-ramen was the perfect sized savory ending 
-balanced and perfectly seasoned

Would recommend and return.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Dinner review. Tasting menu.

Otooshi - 2/5
Tataki - 3/5
Kobujime - 3/5
Tongue - 5/5
Oxtail - 3/5
Yakiniku sushi - 3/5
Tantanmen - 4/5
Panna cotta - 3/5
Brown butter cookie - 3/5

Overall, "A-OK."
author: Mark O.

description:
What a disappointment -- my husband loves the beer and we were so looking forward to trying this restaurant, but in the end the food was lackluster.  

Two of us ordered:

* Tasting menu ($78/person):  Portions were tiny and we felt that we could have had a better meal if we ordered a la carte.  The only dishes we enjoyed were the yakiniku sushi and the tantanmen, though we did appreciate trying the sweet potato ice cream with wagyu fat powder on top.   3/5

* 3.5 oz of the A5 wagyu steak ($125):  This was delicious, but considering how small the piece was and the casual atmosphere, it was definitely a bit overpriced.  But definitely the best thing we ate at the restaurant.  4/5

* Bacon wrapped mochi ($8):  Nice smoky flavor.  4/5

Again -- prices were very high:  our meal for two, including tax and tip, was $400.  Considering we could have had a lovely Michelin 2* dinner for that price, it wasn't worth it.
author: Alice C.

description:
I love Hitachino beer so was excited to try it out as our beer club monthly spot.  When we arrived there was no one inside which was a bit alarming because it's pretty new.  My friends and I sat in the back.  It took a long time for the waitress to explain the menu to us which left us more confused than if we just read it ourselves.  While I know wagyu is very expensive, the amount of food we got for the price we paid was definitely not worth it.  And the flavors didn't blow our socks off either.

We had the Kobujime, sliders, nigiri and tantanmen.  The tantanmen was the best of the meal and offered the most bang for the buck.

If you're a fan of Hitachino beer, I'd recommend just coming for a drink instead of the food based on the price and what you get for it.
author: Blake B.

description:
This place is awesome.  Go and enjoy.

I've eaten my way through most of the menu in my two trips.  The beef tongue is stellar.   Sakes are tasty and the beer speaks for itself.

Friendly staff.
author: Double L.

description:
Tasting Menu is solid. $78
Got different cuts from head to tail. 
Definitely add the sake flight. $40
This place did not upset.
author: G C.

description:
Dear Hitochino Management, 

I've been very loyal to this restaurant over the last few months and have been introducing your bar to close friends. 

Yesterday I was talking up how good your beer is to my friends on the way to your restaurant. I was very disappointed to be turned away from an essentially empty bar (~10-15% capacity) because they had "upcoming reservations." It was 635 and the place was almost empty. 

My friends and I find it very hard to believe that we couldn't be serviced. It ruined the moment. If we needed to be out by 7, that should've been presented as an option. 

Please revisit your customer relations protocols and discuss with your staff to avoid needlessly damaging a good brand, turning away paying customers, losing loyal customers and losing new customers in the future.  

For other readers, the beer is great and waiting service is good. Hosting services and protocols clearly needs improvement.
author: David P.

description:
Exquisite... 

Not sure if SF folks understand this gem 

subtle, exquisite and elegant preparations that seem to honor every aspect of the ingredient into it's fullest expression.

must experience - a celebration of a cuisine, a way, a time honored expression of everything Japanese through food and brew.
author: Rex R.

description: Amazing.  First time at this location and first time wagyu experience.    Very friendly staff, great ambiance and location.  Would def highly recommend and look forward to a return visit soon.
author: Tim O.

description: Very mediocre. I wanted to love this place a lot because I love wagyu and Japanese food, but Hitachino left a lot to be desired. We got the a la carte menu since the set menu was way too expensive. Off the a la carte, we got the sliders, sashimi, rice dish - it's been awhile since I was there, but each dish was really meh. Both cooked and raw wagyu were way too tough to chew on, and didn't have any of that fattiness that melted in your mouth. Overall, it ended up just being a really expensive meal that left me a bit hungry at the end. Not a fan.
author: Jasmine X.

description: Amazing hidden gem at Tender-Nob! Came here for happy hour and was blown away by the variety of great sake and beer selections they have! Sale and cheese paring was such a pleasant surprise! Will definitely come back for dinner.
author: Lynn W.

description:
When I was 14, I sneakingly took a sip of my mom's [Miller] beer when she wasn't looking. 

I cringed. Ewww, why does it taste like a golden shower?!

So much for underage drinking. 

I never took a drink again until I was 27 but ended up getting carried away into the kitchen at Infusion Lounge (Hi, dad!). 

The first time I had a taste of craft beer was just a couple of years ago. I was at a fancy sushi restaurant when I had taste of Hitchino Nest White Ale. I was amazed at how refreshingly light, crisp, and citrusy it was. I'm still not much of a beer person and prefer the hard stuff but Hitachino really opened my eyes at how good beer should taste. Not to mention, the pink owl is cutest beer logo ever. 

Like many, I've been anticipating the opening of Hitachino Beer & Wagyu's first U.S. location in San Francisco. After two failed attempts to get reservations, we finally lucked out last week. After multiple people voicing complaints of trying to compete with 3,000+ people on their mailing list and possible tech bots, Hitachino now has a more equitable lottery based reservation system (sign up for their mailing list to receive the link to be placed in the lottery). Thank you to Luna, the Social Media Manager for promptly responding to everyone's messages and emails. 

Currently, reservations are for their Head-to-Tail Wagyu Tasting Menu ($68 pp): http://bit.ly/2nedMCm. Optional drink pairing is +$30 pp. Beer and sake only. The bar is walk-in only with a small bites/snack menu. 

While waiting for one of our friends who was running late (again), we started with some beers and ordered some small plates from the bar menu. 

As someone who loves ginger, I started with the Real Ginger Brew ($10): http://bit.ly/2mMreum. This was disappointing as it tasted more malty than gingery. The Weizen ($9): http://bit.ly/2mMmsgp was more up my alley - crisp with banana and vanilla notes. My friends really enjoyed the Rotating Barrel Aged Beers: Three-Day Aged and the Sessions ($12). 

On the bar menu, we ordered the Chicken Gizzards, Pork Belly Kakuni, Spicy Squid ($8 each): http://bit.ly/2nWbqoJ. They're all prepared sous vide in a jar and poured onto plates tableside. Sadly, we didn't care for any one of them. They were very bland and had lost all its texture - tasted liked boiled meat. The Spiced Nuts ($8) were a tad better: http://bit.ly/2mMAUVq but lacked a hearty crunch. 

As for the Wagyu Tasting Menu ($68): http://bit.ly/2nedMCm it was a collection of hits and items that were just ok. Portions are small so anticipate possibly needing a second dinner (we went to Halal Guys afterwards).

(1) Otooshi - Wintermelon w/ bonito, 24 carat gold flakes: http://bit.ly/2mMtiCC
(2) Wagyu Tataki w/ smoked tosazu, eggplant, chive: http://bit.ly/2mlhk6K
(3) Kobujime, burrata, edamame, dry tomato, ginger, katsuo-bushi: http://bit.ly/2mMA2jK
(4) Tongue, scallion, yuzukoshou: http://bit.ly/2n0Jpx0
(5) Oden Oxtail w/ daikon, konnyaku, beer mustard (portion for 2): http://bit.ly/2nsiywF
(6) Yakiniku w/ apple, sesame, soy: http://bit.ly/2mMJxzm
(7) Tantanmen w/ spicy sesame broth: http://bit.ly/2mIbmrX
(8) Soy Milk Panna Cotta w/ mandarin orange granite: http://bit.ly/2nWcbhR
(9) Barley Tea (caffeine-free) w/ brown butter cookies: http://bit.ly/2n0JOQ2

Table favorites were the meat skewers and tantanmen. The gyutan had a very light crisp exterior with an incredibly tender interior. Tongue is one of my favorite cuts of meat. Some may cringe at the thought of eating cow tongue but seriously, don't knock it until you try it. The yakiniku was meltingly tender and had a great savory sweetness. The tantanmen was the most substantial thing on the menu and was Japanese comfort food in a bowl. The umami laden broth had great depths of flavor and the noodles were perfectly al-dente. I usually don't like thin, straight noodles but these were really good. 

There was nothing bad about the other items on the tasting menu. They were just very subtle in flavor and a bit underwhelming compared to the yakiniku and tantanmen.

The staff are very polite but there are inevitable service kinks for just having opened. There were long lags between courses as servers were also the food runners. We were only one of two tables when we first arrived and one of three as it got later in the night. Not sure if someone called in sick but they need more staff to expedite orders more promptly especially when they're a full house.

Reservations are hard to come by because Hitachino is not a large space. There's 5 booths, 1 four top, 2 two tops, and 8 seats at the bar. It will be easier for you to get in as a group of 4 than a party of 2 so plan ahead. Thank you for food porn friendly lighting!

Parking can be very challenging so plan to take a lyft or uber here. 

Can't wait until they offer an A la Carte Menu in the future. When they do, stick with the yakiniku and the tantanmen...and wash it down with several $10-$12 glasses of beer because...San Francisco!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I didn't have high hopes coming into this place, my friend really admired their beer so we decided to give it a shot. When you first walk in you can see a great deal went into designing the place but I didn't find any of the design to be anything too interesting. It was a Thursday around 8pm and there was only one other couple inside. It felt very lonely in there. 

We ordered some appetizers, gizzard and squid. I was a bit shocked, the gizzard came out of a sous vide. Not sure how long it had been sitting there but the presentation resembled someone opening a can of baby food and pouring it in front of you. Maybe if there was a mention of this before I placed my order or on the menu I may have ordered differently. You might be wondering about the squid? Well I'm still wondering too because it never made it to my table and I was actually ok with that after seeing the gizzard. 

The food had a decent flavor but was much too mushy for my liking.  The gizzard was so soft that I could barley feel it in my mouth. 

I was hoping to try some wagu but I'm happy I went with appetizers first. The appetizer should prepare you for whats coming next, but it only disappointed me. 

The stout didn't taste like a stout at all. More of a dark larger, again not what I anticipated and not in a good way. 

The place was pricey, so the first shot for me was a miss so I ended up having dinner elsewhere after..
author: Yosof R.

description: This is an amazing little place only 1 year old and fabulous bar food and special sake and cheese pairing is a must! No joke! You'll be pleasantly surprised. Alex is a great sommelier and will keep you very happy!
author: Winnie C.

description:
Not bad not bad! I would give this place 3.5 stars but unfortunately don't have that option. It was busy on a Friday early evening but I was able to snag my friend and I one of the standing tables o the side. My friend and I got a beer each along with a couple bar bites. Beer was good and the food not bad either! All the food comes out in jars and then they pour it out into the plates. They sous vide all of their food which is really interesting and a notch up from regular bar bites you would usually get. Nothing special about the food though, but still pretty decent. Meatballs were probably the best. Would come back again if I was in the area, but there's a lot of other great places in the area as well so competition is high. I'm also not the biggest beer drinker so this review is probably a bit biased as well.

Would be interested in how the tasting menu is as that seems to have great reviews.
author: Megan K.

description:
Nice selection of Hitachino Nest beer on tap - tasty bar bites. Look out for limited edition beers from time to time.

Nest is best!
author: Chris W.

description:
Went to dinner here last night. 
We were the first in the restaurant, so that gave us a weird feeling, but by the time we left, the restaurant was full! 
We splurged on the summer tasting menu, so we can get the feel of the whole menu, will order a la carte next time. 
First course was the Hitachi A5 wagyu Nigiri over garlic sushi rice. Fireworks in the mouth! Warm rice, tender wagyu, this first taste was promising. The uni tempura was next, with wagyu, beer butter, shiso, lightly battered and fried, served with matcha salt. So scrumptious! Then came the nagaimo skewer, mountain yam, with wagyu poké and bonito flakes. A bit salty. The tongue skewer was next, which I gave to my husband.. it has an interesting presentation, the skewer was like floating! Next came the dumplings in a bamboo basket. Two types, the wagyu soup dumpling, like a xiu long bao, and the surf and turf ( wagyu beef with crab and shrimp ) Thai sticky rice dumpling. The rice was undercooked, so it was gritty to chew. The dipping sauce was wonderful! Then came the pork belly chasyu somen noodles, in a soy milk dashi broth and black garlic oil. We ordered the truffle extra. This was so good, we finished everything, broth and all! The Japanese wagyu katsu curry rice was next, it was good, the curry was spicy. Then came the wagyu sandwich, white milk bread. Banana tempura with chocolate sauce was the dessert. I have to say the dessert was a weak finale. I would have preferred a panna cotta ( saw that in previous menu ), or even a simple ice cream. But a fried banana was just not my cup of tea after an excellent wagyu dinner. 
Our server Kevin was awesome!! He explained the menu items with great passion and great details! We can tell he loves what he is doing!! 
Hope the chef would expand the dessert selection, in time for our next visit. 
We were lucky to find a parking spot, but we saw parking garages in the area too.
author: lovetoeat a.

description:
I'm probably gonna be super familiar with every dish on the menu very soon. 
One of the most amazing things here is, they use Japanese rice for the curry instead of American or Chinese rice. 
Love it.

The chef is not Japanese, actually nobody here is...but the look on his face, is so Japanese.. it (at least) looks like he takes his job super seriously ...
The waiters and waitresses here are pretty much on the polite side too. 
Hmm... 
I like their lighting too.... not too dark not too bright. Good stuff!
author: Yumi K.

description:
Note: the tasting menu is wonderful. I ate during their soft opening and it was great value for quality. 
Tasting menu gets 5 stars. 

However their bar a la carte menu was disappointing to say the least...this gets 1-2 stars so 3 star average. 

Happy hour option was just a beer flight for $10 and you couldn't choose which beer. It was their 3 basic ales (white, red, stout). You'll never have a chance to taste their rotating taps. 

For some reason most of their menu is US wagyu instead of hitachi wagyu. The tasting menu had a hitachi wagyu donburi but a la carte uses US wagyu. 

Pricing is a bit ridiculous for the dishes. 
$29 for a small donburi with tough U.S. wagyu meat. Not worth it...most expensive donburi I've ever had and most disappointing. 
$10small/$16 for curry. The stew was like water and had no flavor. For meat that's been stewed in the curry it also had no flavor and was a bit tough. The portions was laughably small. Honestly I would rather buy instant curry for $3 at a store....
$17 for tantanmen. This was actually pretty decent but not $17 good. I would pay about $10 tops especially when the noodles are store bought. 

The 3 dishes were recommended by the servers. None of them were any good. Disappointing since the tasting menu was so good. 

No wonder the restaurant was empty. I for sure would never come back for the a la carte menu. 
If you want noodles go get mensho down the street rather than here. 

If you are thinking of coming just do the tasting menu. They need serious fixing of their a la carte and happy hour.
author: tsubasa m.

description: Went with my boyfriend on Valentines and had the tasting menu. Out of the 9 dishes + 2 desserts, only 2 of them were "blew me away" kind of good, many dishes I can have them at other restaurants paying half of the price. Given that price range I would expect it be a lot more satisfying. I've had more expensive meals elsewhere, when they were actually THAT good, high price tag was fine as long as it was worth it. The visual display was wonderful, but they should put more work into the taste. Overall a good experience, just IMO a bit over priced.
author: Shirley X.

description:
The beer:  Most of their beer was $10-12 per "half a pint" (8 oz), yes not per a pint.  So, if you want to get a pint of beer here, the price would be $20+ per glass.  The beer was tasty but we felt it was really pricey.

The food: We had several small plates and a wagyu dish.  They were all good but the portion was way too small.  Another thing we noticed was that they serve food at your table from canned bottles.  The server had to shake each bottle to get out the food inside onto plates.  I am not sure if it meant to be "hip" or something.  It just gave us an impression that the food was prepared well in advance and preserved for a while (Not cooked freshly for us).  The wagyu was tasty but the portion was really small.

The service:  It was okay.  Our server was nice but didn't come to our table often, which was good and bad.  We wanted to order more but lost opportunities.

The bill was about $130 for two.  For the amount of drinks/food that we had, it was pretty pricey.
author: M Y.

description:
Came here last Friday on a double date with (way) advanced reservations and had the Wagyu tasting menu with Hokkaido uni, foie gras, and wagyu beef donburi supplements and we all leave full and satisfied! We originally planned on going to liholiho for a baked Hawaii afterwards, but did not because we were content.

$78 wagyu tasting menu. $30 beer pairing. We skipped the beer pairing since some of us had happy hour before. 

DRINKS/FOOD
Dai dai ale- pale ale with mikan (small orange) and I liked it
Ume beer- a special not on the menu, with plum, friends liked it as well
Otooshi- presentation was pretty and it was good. Liked that they accommodated my intolerance to dairy
Tataki- the beef was tender and the jelly was very smoky! The foie gras supplement worked well with the dish, but it was delicious without it too
Kobujime- very good, texture of beef was ok, I think I got a chewy piece. Uni supplement was okay in here but the uni was very fresh, I would have enjoyed it alone more
Tongue- one of the best dishes that night, so tender. We all were wow'ed
Oden oxtail- this was tasty and served from canned bottles, it was their method of preparing the dish. Oxtail was super tender and daikon well cooked like it should be
Yakuniku sushi- probably the least favorite if I had to choose. The sushi piece was ginormous. It would have been better if split into two. The butter corn on the side was ok.
Wagyu donburi- this was tasty, we all enjoyed it
Tantanmen- my favorite of the night. The noodles were yummy, like the thinner Hakata ramen noodles which I prefer. The spiciness of the soup was good and better with the added chili paste. Serving size was a lot bigger than we expected and we all were saying how full we were but we all finished it!
Soymilk panna cotta- my friends said this was ok but the lemon curd and the granita that it comes with was yummy. Mine had extra lemon curd in place of the panna cotta which I have no objections to. It was delicious to me
Barley tea & brown butter cookie- perfect way to end the meal. 

DECOR/AMBIANCE
Very nicely decorated place; please see photos.
I love the small touches of the Hitachino owl on the water and beer glasses. So cute! A little dimly lit but comfortable. Sound level was not too loud either.

SERVICE
Great service, our waiter was friendly and described everything in detail, took our orders with no mistakes. Food came out fairly smoothly except for one dish, but it didn't bother us. By the time we finished our meal, there was a line at the door. We weren't rushed to leave though. 

Overall, I had a great time and would return when I feel like wagyu again. It's a great place to take someone who like wagyu- a unique head to tail wagyu tasting experience with a large selection of good Jpn beer. Just need to book in advance! Parking in lower on hill is you know, not easy usually, but since our reservation was at 6pm, a bit early for the typical dinner time, I found parking easily.
author: Iris H.

description:
I was really looking forward to Hitachino for quite a while now and just thought this place was slightly overhyped. I mean, they had exclusive lottery tickets to dine here during the soft opening! For the last tickets available they even turned it into a Haiku contest... wow. That's a little much. 

Anyway, I've always loved Hitachino's white ale and am glad I had the chance to try the different types of beer but nothing beats the original... so I was a little disappointed there. Also, when I came on a Thursday evening it was pretty empty surprisingly.

Also, the food is insanely expensive and served in small portions. Perhaps they are good quality or whatnot, but when I'm at a bar, I expect affordable sliders and skewers... I wouldn't come out of the way to try this place, but if I'm in the area, I'd definitely head in for a glass of beer. By the way, beers are on the pricier side of $10 each.
author: Janet H.

description:
Interesting place. Was here a while back and am backfilling my write up. Came here early after work and it was empty when I peeked in. I hesitated for a second, but went in and shortly after the place was filled and had a queue at the bar. The reservation for tables are full for a well over a month.

I think the experience here will very based on expectation and what you came here for. If you're here for a drink to try out some brews, it's a great location. The snacks here are sous vide (at least when I was here) and may take a while to prep. When I was here, one of my order was forgotten and I had to remind the server to check on it almost 20minutes in. The food here was a little on the bland side, the sous vide did mean that things are very tender. But in all honesty, it's more gimmick and cool factor than taste. I do see a point in keeping the food light to not mess with your taste when tasting the more delicate flavor of their beer, however, i prefer my snacks to be more flavorful.

I'd give this location a 4 star if I was just here for drinks, I probably have a less negative experience as I was one of the first ones int and avoided any wait time. I'd give this place a lower rating (3 stars) if I have to base it off the food and pricing of the snack items. I don't mind paying good a little more for snacks, but it just wasn't to my taste. Overall, I'd give it a 3 as I can imagine what majority of the folks may experience coming and having to deal with the wait. 

in short, stop by for a drink if you see that it's not crazy crowded. Save it for another day if you see something just standing by the door waiting their turn.
author: Alan L.

description:
Their food is very delicious. But their service is horrible...
When the waitress brought our desert with our bill.
She said
" please finish your desert within 10 min ,because next customers are waiting. "
Really???
We had a reservation and our bill was $450 ( 2 people )
It is not cheap.
How come we have to leave....
We don't care " next customers are waiting "
It is your management issue....

We never come back here!!!
author: Iguanatte S.

description:
You know I don't know why people hate on this place so much. 

We sat at the bar and had a great time with the beer and food. 

We didn't order the prixe fixe, but ordered a la carte:
 - tataki
 - koubujime
 - tantanmen
 - soup dumplings
 - potato salad

My personal favorite was the koubujime
Sure the price was a little high. Definitely use the tantan men to fill up. The only really bad item that was the potato salad. We were expecting a creamy salad, but instead it was chunky and was separating a little.
author: Katarina M.

description:
It seems that there are a lot of 5-star or 3-star reviews of this new joint. I'll have to go with the 3-star givers.

Like any good review, and like many written about this place, this restaurant brings up memories past. When I turned 21 (in 2007), I'd like to say that I was growing up in an era where brewing beer was getting popular. I was experimenting with lots of different types of alcohol, especially beer since it fit my cheap budget. I'd go to stores like Bevmo or different drinking establishments and try a lot of different beverages. I remember see Hitachino, in a bottle with a cute label with an owl on it. Oh, and it's Japanese? Must be good. Since those days, I've had random encounters with Hitachino at different restaurants and it was always delicious.

When I learned that Hitachino Beer & Wagyu was opening, I had to try for a spot in the lottery. When I found out I was able to go, I was pretty dang excited.

Everything was delicious--there's no doubt about that. However, I would say that there are lots of kinks that need to be worked out. I went with the prix fixe menu which was $68. I added the drink pairing ($30) and an uni/foie gras pairing ($30). This totaled $128. Was it worth it? No. I mean, damn they're literally charging $15 for a small piece of uni and $15 for some foie gras. They weren't even big or that tasty. I was with friends who didn't get the uni/foie and it was clear that the chefs literally just "tacked it [the uni/foie] on" the side of my dish. I mean, if I'm going to fine dining, I am looking for some artfully designed dishes. If something can just be tacked on (like putting jalapeños on a burger), then it's as if there's no real vision for the dish. The waitress also mentioned in the beginning something about, "this is a head-to-toe experience" where you'll be getting tongue and oxtail. It seemed sort of cheesy that she mentioned this and other than the fact we were served these animal parts, there was no head-to-toe theme about the experience.

There was only one dish that stood out to me, which was indeed the tongue. The small amount of oxtail I got is also worth mentioning. Everything else was just OK.

So, is it worth coming it? Not yet, at least. It is overpriced and the food could be more colorful. If anything, just come here to see if you could snag a seat at the bar and just drink some of their delicious brew that is definitely worth your while (which is why I was so excited in the first place).
author: Marlon T.

description: I'm a big fan of Wagyu and the tasting menu, and more importantly, the wagyu rib-eye steak were good.  Service and ambiance were great and this place offers reasonable value for money.  I really wish they offered a small wagyu rib-eye steak supplement instead of having to order the 1 pound rib-eye (it's a little much).  Also, they put coconut on the tantanmen which added an interesting, but unnecessary, textural element.  The wagyu sushi nigiri is not as good as what you can get at a place like Kusakabe but still really tasty.  Ox tongue was really tender but probably not for everyone.
author: Andrew S.

description:
I'm just not sure how people are rating this 5 stars. I've been grateful to eat at a lot of fancy restaurants and this missed the mark significantly. Got all the supplements and the beverage pairing . Came down to $160 before tip. Beer was good, food was okay. Out of 7 savory dishes , 3 were good. The rest definitely didn't hit the mark. Note, nothing was great. The wagyu was muddled in most courses. The dessert also needs some improvement.

There's definitely a lot of work to be done, service too needs to be improved.

I wouldn't recommend going here just yet.
author: Shivam D.

description:
Came here with reservations on a Thursday night. 
When I walked in, I realized there's a bar.  It wasn't too crowded. We got there 15 minutes before our reservation so we waited at the bar area for about 15 minutes before we were seated.

Their menu was still their grand opening tasting menu at $78pp. I came here with the bf and shared a beer pairing for $30.

Food was alright. The first 3-4 items were one biters. Although it was a wagyu tasting menu, there wasn't a lot of wagyu served... each dish had some sort of domestic wagyu but each piece was like a thin sliver. I get it-- it's a tasting menu... so I guess it's just a taste? Hahaha~

The most memorable items there were the cow tongue on a skewer... and the yakiniku sushi.  that tongue literally melts in your mouth! The ramen and some of the other dishes were just alright.

After reading some reviews, I had low expectations of the food and didn't expect to get full. We were actually planning to go to Halal Guys afterwards. The food wasn't bad and I left perfectly full! The bf left pretty full too. I guess Halal Guys will have to wait for another day. 

Our server Robert was friendly, gave good suggestion for beer, and explained each dish. Seemed like there were only two servers that night... but I guess it is a pretty small restaurant!

The beer pairing? It was good! They choose 3 small glasses and we get to choose the 4th in a regular sized glass. All the glasses combined pretty much adds up to a total of 3 glasses of beers. We got the amber ale, a plum ale (not on menu), a third I forgot (not on menu), and we chose the dai dai. 

Next time, I think I'll just go straight to the bar for beer!  so far, I would give 3.5 stars, but there's no such option.
author: Carin S.

description:
jars! jars! jars jars jars!
jars! jars! jars jars jars!
start w straight jars n then pop owls
start w straight jars n then pop owls

i sat down chizzef nori started clapping to welcome me whoa. he and yagisawa (architect dude who made the shelves) are from hitachi. like the tvs & electronics THAT same hitachi. "nest" is a pun on the og brewery town name + owl good luck omen now you're up to speed on the past 300 years! i asked him all that lol.

yes jarfood barfood no don't be scrrrrd it's all plated like you'd expect w tapas n the jar effect is like sous vide everything.

(^_^) Spicy Squid $8 (http://bit.ly/2m0E1Zt)
ate it all then wanna drink the broth

(^_^) Beef Suji Nikomi $8 (http://bit.ly/2n4dRpJ)
superrr tender oxtail from warm jar bath

(^_^) Pork Belly Kakuni $8 (http://bit.ly/2lCAh4q)
mixed softness, overall good n mm egg

(^_^) Chicken Gizzard $8 (http://bit.ly/2n4qJw9)
also really tender eat the whole peppers

(-_^) Garnish Meatball $8 (http://bit.ly/2m0QlsK)
soft. not bad

(-_^) Potato Salad $7.5 (http://bit.ly/2n49A5H)
different from black potato salad

(-_^) Octopus Sunomono $8 (http://bit.ly/2mhjIYO)
ty for real chopped wasabi vs paste

i tore through all 6 meat jars then even got a veg jar. i also want to try the tasting menu not bc wagyu but bc grits! seasonly / monthly rotating food & drink means recheck later too.

great service dopeeeeee music old blues incl some of my very faves john lee hooker, elmore james what an atmos. and the geometric hedron origami sosick.

4.5ish fun times.
author: Dan B.

description:
What a fun option for a bunch of beer nerds also in the mood for non-pub food! Loved the sliders and short rib. The portions were better than expected, the flavors exceptional (especially for umami fans) and the vibe made for an excellent night.

We'll be back again soon - got our eye on the tasting menu for a special occasion ;)
author: Christine Y.

description:
I've been following this opening for quite some time. The unicorn of Japanese Beers; wanted to hit up the brewery itself when I was in Japan but would've required a car rental and quite an adventure to Nagasaki from Tokyo. That being said:

Beer selection: unexpected draft varietals, the 8% Ginger Beer was almost kombucha-like, loved the espresso stout. Lots of beers that I've never had. Had only had the Red Rice Ale, and White Ale that's served in bottles here. Quite a treat.

Food: you basically need to order a thing or two to cut the taste between beers. We used the pork belly and the kimchee style pickles. Perfect beer compliment.

Ambiance: a little contrived, but friendly, you can walk in and order a beer. If you want to really enjoy the wagyu beef and be treated like a queen: get a reservation.
author: jacob m.

description:
Amazingly delicious all the way around. Came here for the happy hour on a Saturday, yes Saturday at 4:30pm even through yelp states they're not open until 5:30pm (they should fix that). The food was great and the portions are plentiful. We tried the sake cups and one flight of beer, both left us wanting more.

I highly recommend this place!!
author: Loren A.

description:
Food: meh, which is unfortunate when wagyu is the star. The beef felt like a garnish on most dishes. Presentation needs a load of work. Tart and tsukune did not look appetizing nor offer much beef flavor. Tataki looked like someone mushed a buncha orange Jello on it. Tantanmen was fine. Wagyu barely needs accompaniment - my opinion is that they really overdress it to the point that the thin sheets of beef they include are lost. Absolutely not worth the $76 prix fixe. Did not try the $95 add-on ribeye (1 lb) nor the $125 add-on 3.5 oz of wagyu, but not compelled due to lowered expectations meal. 

Service: great. Thanks for complimentary anniversary ale!

Ambiance: So-so. Little too bright. Tables are low relative to bench.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Came here with a group of 5, we tried all different food and beers.  The food was totally over priced, the beef which is suppose to be the star of the restaurant was not cooked or presented in a way to show off the quality of the meat.  My boyfriend had the flight of beers selected by the waiter, the espresso stout was really the only one he liked.  The food was subpar, the place has an okay concept, just not executed well at all.  

However, our waiter was pleasant and knowledgeable...there are so many other amazing restaurants in the city which I would have much rather dined at!
author: Alexa O.

description:
Huge fan of the Hitachino beers. I don't mind paying $10 per glass on draft, even though they were served in smaller glasses - it's an expensive beer in general. Interior was plain and tidy, I imagine closely replicating a small Japanese locale. 

I expected everything to be incredibly delicious considering the cost of the food. The starters we got - octopus and radish - were good, not great. I got the raw wagyu "salad?". It was cute and served on a nicely seasoned piece of burrata (why?) and came with a small side of uni. It was an interesting attempt with good flavors all around but fell flat conceptually, which makes me sad for forking over $28 for it. For whatever reason, our ramen took forever - it was the best part of the meal (rich broth, didn't love the noodles) and also the most reasonably priced. 

We left feeling underwhelmed and uninspired to return. 2 beers each + 2 starters + raw wagyu "salad" + bowl of ramen + Saratoga bottled sparkling = $110 for 2 people. What really irked me was the "tipping guide" at the bottom of the receipt started at 20%, then showed 22% and 25%. This is not a fine dining establishment where service is above and beyond where you'd actually consider giving a 25% tip.  

The only thing that will bring me back is the great beer - too many other good places to spend my money in SF. I give it 2 solid eye rolls.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Well, this place is overpriced given both the quality and quantity food is subpar... The cooking didn't really show the beauty of the meat and flavor is medicore. Nice concept but poor execution.

Maybe a nice place to drink some beer, but certainly not for dinner.
author: Barry W.

description: Everything was nice but I just can't justify the prices. Seriously beyond the pale overpriced!
author: Manny F.

description: Love Hitachino's beer but the food is disappointing and incredibly overpriced. Do not order the gyoza. Don't do it. I feel like I always need to order gyoza because I absolutely love it, and upon first glance Waygu gyoza sounds amazing. It's expensive at Hitachino, I'll give it that. Unfortunately, it isn't very flavorful or well seasoned. The Waygu does nothing for this gyoza, and I would have been much happier with a regular pork gyoza elsewhere for half the price. We tried a few dishes, and all were overpriced and nothing to write home about. The beer, however, is still great. I'd go to the bar just for a beer but nothing else.
author: Justin G.

description: Was so great from both a food and atmosphere perspective. Could not believe how knowledgeable the staff is. The quality of food taste is equaled by the knowledge of the staff and the significance of the history behind Hitachino. Thank you!
author: Scott J.

description:
Worst bar I've went to.
Food is too little, price is expensive.
Would go to any other bar if I could.
Only good thing about this place is their sake.
author: Moon K.

description: The only reason for 4 star as I have no idea how is l good Is the food, but it looks like people enjoy it a lot. However beer selection is amazing, especially if you like Japanese wheat beer, awesome music, relax and quiet atmosphere.  friendly staff , this spot is perfect!
author: Pavel K.

description: The menu was limited and had few selections - honestly not worth the price. Disappointing service and all around ambiance.. NOT high expectations since I live across from this hipster restaurant -  frequent the adjoining ZZAN (better for quality). Upsetting since I could hear staff gossiping about us. Overpriced ramen best course.. please keep looking if your not interested in patronizing service. Not tonight..
author: Bryce P.

description: Ahhh, everything was so good!! I was able to talk to the owner chef and he is so passionate about bringing quality Wagyu with quality beer. The nigiri was just amazing!!!
author: Yoko H.

description:
Awesome staff and great bear and sake!!
I and my husband stopped by at the end of our San Fransisco trip. Visit here made our trip a very special one!  The manager and chef were super nice!! We used to go to Hitachino bars in Japan, but this one is one of the best of all!! We would love to go back very soon!
author: Ayumi N.

description:
Big fan of Hitachino beers, so I was thrilled to learn they had their own taproom in SF. Great selection of Japanese craft beers and they are definitely devoted to the art of well-marbled beef. We enjoyed every dish we ordered, especially the wagyu curry and wagyu ribeye steak. They do use American wagyu, but I honestly thought it was still some of the best beef I've had.

It is a bit of a niche establishment and it is not cheap, so I can see how maybe it isn't for everyone.   For the price you can definitely eat at some of the nicer restaurants in SF. But I don't see why Hitachino wouldn't be up there. If you enjoy Asian-style beers and love the craft of beef in general, then this place is definitely worth checking out.
author: Rob C.

description: I get the low reviews now. This place has a huge number of service staff, but only one waitress, and she's not super knowledgeable. We had a 7:00pm reservation for four on Saturday, but even though our table was ready when we got there, we were left at the bar to wait for half an hour until we asked about our table, which was empty and prepped the whole time. Not only we're so many of the taps out, but they told us that there is only a tasting menu. When we told them we didn't want to do it and were just going to drink, they gave us the a la carte menu that didn't exist. Our waitress then continued to explain to us that many of the items weren't available anyway. How's the food and drink? Beers are generally sour and tart, so not quite in my wheelhouse, but also not quite explained properly in the menus and not all available. When asked about my first two picks, our waitress said neither were available anymore. The food was whatever. Pork belly bar bite? Huge chunks of fat with almost no meat. Same flavor as you would from your Chinese mama braising pork belly, but with no actual meat. Gizzards and thighs? Extremely overcooked. Meat was springy and tasted like it had been sitting in a pot for too long. Tongue skewers? Most people who have had it enjoyed it, but honestly, it just tasted like squares of liver. The garnish on top was identical to a Chinese scallion and ginger dipping sauce for Hainan chicken. I thought this place was supposed to be Japanese? Why are almost all of the flavors Chinese? They have a lot of work to do.
author: Danny C.

description:
Food and drinks are good but way overpriced.

I had the small beef curry plate which was good but not great. Something was lacking in that dish that I just couldn't figure out.

Once is enough for me.
author: Evan W.

description:
Naw! All the hype with their soft opening! 

DISAPPOINTED from my visit. 

Awful... They do not have "all" the Hitachino beer on tap or bottles! So pointless. 

Food C+
author: Madhusudhan R.

description:
Go for it. If you are on the fence regarding this place then don't hesitate. I highly recommend. Blown away by both the food and the beer - especially the beer w/ ume (plum). 

9-course tasting menu for $78. Where else you can get that in SF? 

Food is prepared at Michelin star restaurant quality and artistry. Look, it's no joke. I have been to many Michelin star restaurants before and I know what those type of food taste and look like (just look up my previous reviews on Yelp). Hitachino is in the similar league.
author: George C.

description:
Went yesterday and our table of two ordered the tasting menu, one beer pairing, and two glasses of sake. Let me tell ya, you can get a lot more for the price elsewhere in the city. Either at that price point or for far less. I think this is the first time I've ever left a dinner or tasting menu still hungry! The food was pretty forgettable at that. 

I was pretty excited about this place reading about it leading up to the opening and kept the reservation despite the SF Weekly review. Whoops. Should have taken heed and stayed away.
author: Jeff S.

description: I can't give it 5/5 because while the beer was great and varieties and choices that are unusual... the prices here are steep... even for sf! And also none of us are here not even the bar snacks... the decor is great and the beer is wonderful... I admit to being a beer nerd so I was delighted to try all of their brews, 10$ for a half glass?! Anyway... if you are trying to impress a date or have an original Japanese experience drop off here... not if you are out for a session!
author: Reg B.

description: Hitachino beers have been a favorite, but the ones tasted here were quite surprisingly terrible. The low rating, however, is due largely to what can only be perceived as pretentiousness and a failure to appreciate food for what it is. The menu had a fixed dinner option (approx. $80/person) that was available only by a lottery system of those who signed online, and they've only had several soft openings (four is what is heard as the current tally) at this point. Rather than resorting to marketing gimmicks to make themselves more attractive, might want to focus on the quality of drinks and food to draw in customers. Certain food options on their bar menu were already sold out. And our server wouldn't stop talking about how they would be adding "foie gras" and "uni" to their dishes, but couldn't explain why those ingredients would enhance or otherwise work with the other ingredients of the dish. Simply adding caviar, foie gras, or uni with no cohesion to the overall dish is commonly used to mark up prices or make them seem fancier to the ignorant. Disappointed. Likely not to return.
author: Kimberly H.

description: Very nice their food is good the people that work there are nice cozy place burgers are good can have a little bit more fries the drinks are alright I enjoyed it
author: Mike B.

description: they now have 3.5 oz japanese A5 for $125. But the piece i tried was sinewy in every bite.  I probably left as much beef in my napkin as in my stomach.  At these prices that makes it hard to justify returning, no matter how skilled the chef may be.
author: H S.

description: The bf and I were really impressed with their white ale which we had during a night out at daigo sushi. So once we realized that we've been walking by this restaurant all this time, we were super excited to go try out their other draft selection asap! We stepped in and decided to not take up space in their dining area and just grab a couple beers at the bar. I started to feel very unwelcome by the bartender and his demeanor towards us. He treated us with this superiority and acted almost as if we were flies.. it's so disheartening because we had a place for this place in our hearts even before we got there. High anticipation to become regulars went down the drain fast. We finished up our beers and went to izakaya rintaro to have dinner and drinks where we were so warmly welcomed. Service was so out of touch at hitachino.. I have never felt so unwelcome in my life.
author: Elle K.

description:
Drunkenly stumbled in here the other night solo. The bartender took me in, gave me samples of some very unique tasting Japanese beers, and told me the quick story behind the place. Apparently, it was only the 2nd night that they were open and I had no idea! My favorite beer that I ended up having a 10oz pour of was the red rice beer. A little too sweet for more than one, but definitely a delightful beer that went well with my beef stew that I ordered from the bar bites menu. They are doing limited reservations only right now for the table seating / tasting menu, but looks like you can come in and sit at the bar to order the small bites. 

I'll be back for the tasting menu soon hopefully!
author: Ryan O.

description:
I went earlier this week for the tasting menu. I was SO excited - my boyfriend and I are obsessed with Hitachino beer, and had been honored that they were opening in SF. We got in as soon as we could! Unfortunately, the tasting menu was a big disappointment. The beer was still AMAZING - loved all the new kinds we got to try - but the food was a let down. So, 5 stars for stopping in for a beer, 2 stars for dinner.

Specifically, the food was good but very small and very expensive, the service was atrocious, and the meal took over 3 hours (lots of waiting). Our table of 4 paid $440 + tax + tip and I thought the experience was very meh - for that price, I would want something pretty special. 

I won't bore you with all the details of service, so I'll just describe our first beer order as an example. When we first sat down, we all got the beer/sake pairing. They asked us what drinks we wanted to start, so we ordered some, assuming that it was the full-sized drink included in the pairing. It wasn't - just an extra beer - which felt a little bad/taken advantage of, but it was fine since we were happy to drink more of their tasty tasty beer. Soon they brought us a set of beers different from what we ordered. The waitress asked us to repeat our orders and we did, and she told us they were out of one, so we replaced it with a different one. After some confusion, she took the first round of beers away (I don't know if they were for a different table or what). Then a different waitress comes to tell us that that they were out of one of the beers (which we knew already). We told her we'd already placed a replacement order. Then a new waitress told us there was a problem with the kegs, and that we wouldn't have our beer for a while. All in all it took forever to get our beers, which we were unknowingly paying extra for, and it was a really confusing and disruptive process getting them.  I think maybe they are still working on the kinks but I wanted to let y'all know about my experience in the meantime.
author: Maia B.

description:
Food is solid, but for the premium I just don't feel the value is there. We paid $380 for two people and I didn't feel the value was there. The staff is super friendly and the ambiance is great, but for the price I just wasn't blown away. 

But I also understand the cost of doing business in San Francisco and understand why they need to charge these prices.

I won't return for a full dinner, but would go back for light bites and drinks.
author: Joseph C.

description:
I have been waiting for Hitachino to open officially for a while. Followed a lot of the articles with anticipation. Who doesn't love beer and meat? And not just that, wagyu! 

I arrived about twenty minutes early, but waited at the bar. They have a beer menu on the wall with varieties that I believe aren't readily available at most places. I have only seen a few at Total Wine, but it's never the same as drinking it at a bar when it's on tap. They had a seasonal beer, but I went with the red rice ale as it sounded pretty interesting. Smooth tasting, slightly sweet - I could imagine drinking this daily. I ordered a tongue skewer to start since I figured even after we ordered, it would still take a little time to get some food. The tongue skewer was amazing and I am now a lover of yuzukoshou!
Even though the table was ready early, they said I could finish my snack at the bar and just let them know when I was ready. 
Dinner is based on a pri fixe menu that is $78 per person. They have add ons depending on what is fresh, like Hokkaido uni or soft shell crab. If you are super hungry, they have add ons like US or Japan grown wagyu steaks (the Japanese one is more expensive, of course). 
Overall, I really enjoyed dinner. Service pretty good. The standouts were the wagyu tongue skewers, the oden, and the soy milk panna cotta (can I order that from the bar?). The wagyu dishes were good, but like a few other people have mentioned, the slices are a bit too big so it was hard for me to eat. Not that it meant that it tasted bad, but the difficulty level went higher than needed. 

Either way, I recommend giving them a try, even if it's just a trip to the bar. The bar food is good, and the beer is fantastic! To read more - 
https://gastromonkey.blogspot.com/2017/05/san-francisco-ca-hitachino-beer-wagyu.html
author: Christina L.

description: Service is good , but their Wagyu is too fatty and can't chew off. Tried their yuzu beer nothing to shout about
author: Sy F.

description: What a fun gem in SF! Been a fan of Hitachino for years and was so happy to discover their first bar in the US! We ordered wagyu for my babes and tasty grilled veggies for me. Complemented very well with our deliciois two beers. Perfect start to a great date night!
author: Nicole D.

description:
My bf is a huge fan of Hitachino, and we waited for half a year in anticipation of this opening! We went during the first opening week for the tasting menu, and had a great time. To be honest the tasting menu, while conceptually interesting and encompassing a good variety of dishes, did not wow us and was probably not worth the $68. The dish I enjoyed the most and would come back for if it were a la carte was the tantanmen! It was really unique and flavorful, and both the noodles and broth were delicious! 
On the other hand, the drinks did not disappoint! The white ale on draft was amazing and one of the best beers I've had (Tho I'm not a huge beer drinker) They also have a rotating selection of specialty brews and the Amber Ale was my bf's favorite among  those. And since they are both a restaurant and bar, you can just drop in and order drinks and bar snacks (jars) without a reservation. Will definitely be back to visit the bar!
author: Audrey G.

description: I've loved this brand for years but this place is just disappointing. The interior and decor are nothing special, in fact it's rather generic. The value; well this is SF and you expect to pay up for a good dinner, but there's a difference between 'expensive' and 'overpriced'. Hitachino Beer & Wagyu is overpriced. It leaves you with that sick feeling of being ripped off. I've paid a lot more for dinners in this town but i've never walked away feeling like a sucker. The service; the only word that comes to mind is 'strange'. There's a pervasive pretentiousness that doesn't match the basic atmosphere and lackluster food. Lastly, the food itself; like another reviewer so aptly put it... meh. It's not good. It's average at best. In a town with amazing grub on every corner, I just don't see how this place survives past the six-eight months of opening night buzz. What a bummer.
author: Helmut R.

description:
2.5 for food. 4 for service. 4 for atmosphere.

I love anything that comes out of the Hitachino Brewery. Their SAISON and WHITE ALE being my favorites, but I was very satisfied in the range of offerings on tap. The RED RICE ALE was very interesting. I'd like to come regularly to drink the beers; however, they are pricey by SF standards. 

To the WAGYU TASTING. First off, it's not Japanese Wagyu, it's Washugyu. Washugyu is a cross breed between a Japanese and American cow. 

Also, get the pairing. Beer and Sake (generous pours), it's why you're there. 

Highlights: 
BEEF TONGUE - Best tongue I've had since I can remember. I wish the Yuzukoshou was stronger, but man, I wish I could order more of this. 
TANTANMEN - I was full (from the drinking) by the time it got to the noodle course, but this was really good. 
ODEN OXTAIL - Well executed with a lighter than expected broth and the oxtail was soft and not chewy, which can be the case if not cooked well. 

Everything else was not as delicious / executed well to me. I was excited for the YAKINIKU course, but the piece I got was very chewy. 

Service was great. Our 4th person was over 45 minutes late and our server never fret. She also let us customize our Beer and Sake tasting. 

I'll definitely be back to drink beer at their beautiful bar and try their bar foods (dishes prepared in sake glasses).
author: Patrick M.

description:
A really cool spot! We came because we are fans of Hitachino beer, and the food was all great as well! The wagyu angle was interesting, we had the short rib, tongue, and slider. The short rib was braised for 48 hours and was delicious!

We really liked the ambiance, service, and music (not too loud). A very chill place we will visit again.
author: Mike L.

description:
Total garbage which is just awful to have to say.

Had a reservation at 8pm, was finally seated at 8:30pm. So in the 30min wait, I experience the bar which is over priced $10 6oz beer with poorly cooled sweet beer which had a odd taste like the tap lines haven't been cleaned. Took one spit of the beer and left it. 

Moving on to ordering, waiter was very nice but could have used a pen and paper as he tried to memorize our order but failed to bring one item which he forgot.

The food:
Sliders: A $10 silver dollar medallion of wagyu on a hard and salty pretzel bun. All I could taste was the salt. Its Wagyu beef, why would you ruin it with salt? A McDonalds hamburger would have been more enjoyable.

Gyoza: $25 for 6. Mixture was ground Wagyu with green onion I believe. Over fired and caramelized. The mixture in 2 of them was stringy with tendons, shows poor prep and lack of care.

Curry & Rice: The saddest little portion of Japanese Curry I have ever seen. If you want real Japanese Curry go anywhere else. You will get a mound of rice covered in curry. 

Skip this one.
author: Steve H.

description: Yummy drink selection and food choices. Service was great for our group that came by on a Friday night. I ate a bit before I came here so I only got a few small plates but I want to do the full tasting menu in the near future!
author: Rose Z.

description:
Overpriced.  Not particularly tasty.  Small portions.  So small.

The wagyu powder ice cream was interesting but not good.
author: Sarah S.

description: We had the $78 tasting menu.  Everything was great. The cooking is sophisticated; quality of the ingredient is top notch; and the service is very courteous.  Also, they have a yuzu wine that's absolutely delicious - if you like a hint of sweetness like I do.  I hope to return when they refresh the menu.
author: Judy H.

description:
I arrived around ten pm on Thursday - there were some people at the bar, and a few tables empty. The hostess just pointed to the bar area - and I guess didn't want us sitting at a table. It wasn't really the service you expect when you are ready to spend 250 on beef. So we walked out and didn't try. 

Pro tip: you might want to get trained front of the house team members to properly greet and seat guests.
author: Tom W.

description: Reservation thru Resy on a Saturday night was easy. Not sure if it was an off night but I remember how hard it was to try to get into this place months ago so we were psyched to secure a spot. We were excited for the menu ... Who doesn't love beef and beer and we're talking the best of both! Neither disappointed... For beer, I stuck with my white ale while my husband enjoyed both the Dai Dai and the Classic since he's more of an IPA guy. I've always like Hitachino Nest white for its crisp slightly citrusy flavor.  I tried to focus on how the beer combined with the food but the first item that came out was the nigiri and DAMN! That just stood on its own! I forgot I had the beer right there as I just wanted to shove the 2nd of the 2 nigiri orders into my mouth ;-) A ka-pow of beefy goodness just made every one of my taste buds do the happy dance. We also split an order of the tongue (I thought this was good but slightly too "tonguey") and the bacon mochi. I am not that big of a mochi fan but I enjoyed how this was put together... Gooey mochi and crispy bacon.  Our final order was the 1lb ribeye steak over garlic rice. Wow!!! So much fatty goodness it was hard to stop but finally the arteries started signalling to go for the box after about 3/4ths of it. Probably could have polished it off if not for the appetizers. The rice is the perfect side for this steak, nicely soaked up all the flavors so not a drop was wasted. As mind-blowing as the food, drink and atmosphere of this restaurant were, I must admit we were somewhat disappointed by 3 things -- #1 We ordered the kobujime but the waiter completely forgot about it (not a big deal since it would have been too much already) #2 The tasting menu wasn't available that night (passable, we probably weren't going to go for it anyway) but #3 is IMHO inexcusable ... no dessert menu?!? I guess the dessert chef was out but it would have been nice to have been offered something sweet in the end... anything ... even an ounce of sweet sake to make up for the anti-climactic end of the meal. Yeah, yeah we didn't go in there for the dessert but around SF most other places would *try* to right this wrong (missing menu item) with something else.
author: Melinda V.

description: I consider myself to have a sophisticated palate.  There are only a few foods I don't appreciated.  Okra, lutefisk.  I suppose it's possible that this restaurant is serving food at a higher plane than I have experienced in my 30 years of dining around the world with a generous budget. Maybe it's beyond my level of comprehension, beyond my peasant sensibilities.  But after our $500. dinner for 3 tonight, I just have to say, no.  Emperors new clothes.
author: catherine c.

description: I was there when this place opened today but the guy that worked there said they are sold out unless you have a reservation. There was 2 people there at 11am but you cannot even  sit at the bar when the place is empty.
author: Naomi S.

description: I did the tasting menu here and it was ok. Some dishes were better than others. I love that they are trying some cool and unique, and the dining experience was very fun. However, some of the meat dishes were ok and hard to taste because they were doused in the sauce. The cost of the tasting menu was pretty high as well. I would recommend just doing the a la carte.
author: Nick Y.

description:
Review after 1 visit. I'm a big fan of the Hitachino Nest Red Rice Ale, so when I found out this place opened up, I was pretty interested. Overall impression is that it's a nice, hip spot, and if you're a fan of Hitachino Nest (or beef), you should check it out, and I'd be interested in seeing how the place evolves, but I'm not particularly raring to come back.

We did the tasting menu with some beers. The flight can be a decent introduction to Hitachino beers (or if you like the standard set); they also have some brews that are harder to find (like the sakura barrel-aged Red Rice Ale).

Impressions of the dishes:
-Otooshi (3 *): avocado puree. Not bad.
-Tataki (4 *): pretty nice texture on the meat. Great eggplant vinaigrette. They offer a foie gras addition for $16; not really worth it in my opinion (just a slice of refrigerated foie gras added to the dish).
-Kobujime (3.5 *): I liked this with the burrata, but others at the table found it a bit much. They offered a Hokkaido uni addition ($16); pretty decent quality.
-Tongue skewer (4.5 *): Amazing texture; just a little bit salty.
-Oden beef cheek (3.5 *): Just a little meh on the flavor. I can see why they chose to go with beer mustard, but I prefer the more traditional kind with this dish.
-They ran out of yakiniku sushi (I think), so we got some beef in a soy-milk broth (3.5 *). Not bad, but again, a bit salty.
-Tantanmen (4 *): I was surprised how good this was, with decent noodle texture. The broth isn't super stand-out, but a good finish to the meal.
-Soy milk panna cotta + mandarin orange granita (3.5 *): Nice; not too sweet. A bit heavy on the granita.
-Barley tea + brown butter cookie (3 *): barley tea is a nice touch, but this one wasn't the most flavorful; the cookie is utterly forgettable.

Miscellaneous:
-Total was about $450 for 4.
-We had a reservation for 9:00, but didn't get seated until after 9:30; it's a small place, so you might expect these sorts of fluctuations in timing.
-It seems that their menu can change during the night (the nigiri, and also I think our otooshi). This might be due to the aforementioned low n issue.

I could see myself bumping this rating up on a return visit.
author: M N.
