description: Second visit. Impressed by everything I tasted. Very rich. An interesting and enjoyable dining experience.
author: Lerin S.

description: The food beer sake and wine are incredible and everything here is delivered with craft and care. Get the hitachiwagyu tasting menu!
author: Beau T.

description: This place rocks not only does it have my fav beer - white ale - but the beefs rocks. They play old school hip hop so u know it's sweet
author: Dan A.

description:
$300 for two people all-in. And we didn't even get a strip of grilled wagyu steak! You come for the wagyu/beer/sake, yet they managed to be out of stock on the first two things we asked for (a particular sake, japanese wagyu)

Add $100 more per person for the US wagyu (can't do a-la-carte, has to be with tasting menu), or $135 for japanese "hitachi-wagyu". We tried to order one of the japanese wagyu, but they were out of it??? At a wagyu restaurant with two steaks on the menu? 

A pound of US wagyu for $100 seemed crazy given the delicateness of the tasting menu + price + the fact that US wagyu pales next to something like A4 or A5. We passed.

About half of the courses have wagyu in them, but there is so much going on that you miss out on the flavor profile of wagyu meat. The tongue and tantamen were both incredible.

For a Japanese wagyu restaurant in SF I fully expected A5 Kobe to be somewhere on the menu. Instead the beef is from Nebraska, or their own wagyu from Japan. Staff was not informed to the level of telling me about the beef, what is different about it, etc.

My reference point: I love beer and have had lots of wagyu in Japan and have cooked A5 at home. 

Save some money and go find a butcher in SF who will sell you a US wagyu 1 lb ribeye for $40, and pick up a $5 hitachino white on the way home. Then go get some wagyu nigiri at Kinjo to see what wagyu really can taste like.
author: Scott N.

description:
Disappointing

Pros: food and beer quality: 3.5,  service: 3.5 
Cons: client-unfriendly pricing model: 0.0 
Price: $412 for two

Hitachino's business model is one of a restaurant squeezing all they can out of the Bay Area economy, and if you decide to stay, be prepared to pay a hefty sum ($412+ for two) to keep from going home hungry. Note, the staff was friendly and attentive, but not the best at describing the menu--we were confused.

Summary: were excited about the opportunity to try Hitachino beer on tap and wagyu beef, but did not expect a difficult to discern, 8-course prix fixe menu that included only one dish containing a tooth-sized sliver of wagyu beef. So what does this mean? You must pay $106 for a 16oz Sonoma steak, or $160 for a 4oz cut of Hitachi wagyu on top of the $78 per person menu. The wait staff knows that there isn't enough food on the set menu to satisfy an adult, so they offer either uni or foie gras @ $32 per plate extra--so your choice is to either spend the extra $ or go home hungry after dropping $78 a head + drinks.

In hindsight, we should have walked out--like the table next to us did--but ended up staying (for over 3 hours!), biting the bullet, and ordering the 16oz Sonoma steak, which earned a solid 4.0. The eight-course menu of primarily bite-sized servings earned a 3.0, totaling 3.5. However, we both became ill when returning home, which only added injury to insult. 

In short, there are far better options all around the City where the ownership shows appreciation for its customers. We will not be back.
author: P. C.

description:
$10-$12 glasses of beer and $70 tasting menu in the dining area?  La Folie anyone?  The Wagyu isn't even from Japan.  I wish this restaurant and all of it's employees luck.  I don't think it will be around for long if they don't switch things up.  If you want Wagyu, head over to 5A5 or Alexander's.  If you want slivers of Wagyu from Wisconsin, this is your place.

Despite what others might say, this is nowhere near Michelin level.
author: Rick N.

description: Wow, wtf is this garbage? Ok, lets be fair, I was excited when I heard they were opening a Hitachino joint and Wagyu as well? A must visit! They charge a premium price for premium beer, understandable, but the food leaves a truck load to be desired. Sorry, but I expect my wagyu to be served teppanyaki style, with a variety of different regions to choose from (Kobe is overrated trust me, and it isn't even the best. My friends from Japan tell me to try Akita or Matsusaka beef). Maybe consider serving what they serve at izakaya's in Japan? Yakitori? Robatayaki?
author: Panchali S.

description: Came here at around 1030pm on a Saturday night. Bartender said they were closed. There were people drinking there at the time. Hours posted says they close at midnight. I'll spend my money elsewhere.
author: A B.

description: Can we lower the beer on tap prices? I think $10 is too high ?
author: Rhea J.

description: This place is amazing! The food is absolutely delicious and the beer pairings were spot on!! A lot of negative reviews seem to be from people who didn't do the tasting menu, so I can't speak to that, but do yourself a favor and do the tasting menu with the beer pairing and I guarantee you will leave in a state of fullness and ecstasy. I'm going again with friends tomorrow night and I can't wait!!
author: Nicki L.

description: Wtf the place was empty when I came and the manager said I still needed to make a reservation. Ended up leaving. To the owner, you just lost business
author: Leslie M.

description: We were really excited to try something new.   The bartender was lovely. And helpful ...and we liked the folks at the bar, and we saw some cool food being consumed at the bar ... it started well.  When we got to the table we were told our only choice was the tasting menu, which we could supplement or add on to. Despite the fact that we repeatedly told our server that our one friend was very particular and would not eat half the tasting menu and that my husband only wanted his own steak, we were told we (the whole table) all must order the entire tasting menu. There was no other alternative.  So we did ..and my husband ordered the $95 steak ON TOP of it (which was so fatty that 10 out of the 16 ounces was unrendered  inedible fat. Our friend only ate 1/3 of the courses..... and at the end of the meal we heard from a different waiter that there was an A LA CARTE menu that was never offered to us ...which would have solved all of our problems...and we were PISSED!!! As foodies, as San Franciscans who dine out ..as customers...we were totally disrespected and taken advantage of...and sadly...we will NEVER eat here again.  Happy Anniversary & happy birthday to us... our gift was a kick in the teeth....Had they listened to us at all, and given us the option of  a la carte menu that we asked for repeatedly ... and not treated us so poorly ...we might have tried again..,, we remain really upset and deeply disappointed.  I actually feel defrauded...
author: Heather S.

description: This place has a great sake / beer selection, and the food was also delicious. I'm a huge fan of the wagyu nigiri and tongue skewers. Awesome flavors and space for a night out with friends!
author: Judy H.

description: Great beer and great bar food. Bacon-wrapped mochi is perfection and the Wagyu dishes were all divine.
author: A V.

description: Highest possible rating. Five stars are inadequate. My boyfriend and I have been here twice in four days because we could not stay away. Dinner here is a transformational experience. The chef's talents are beyond exceptional. On our first visit, my boyfriend (a foodie) had the tasting menu, and it literally brought tears to his eyes, it was so good. I had wagyu tantanmen ramen both times, and it could not be better. Please...do yourself a favor and go here. It will be the best food you've ever had, as it was for us.
author: Kris J.

description: Great beer choices, appetizer are not bad but only appetizers not ramen or other entree available, maybe because it's still at soft opening. They serve appetizer in a glass can to keep fresh.
author: Jialu P.

description: We went here last Friday for dinner.  We were only given the tasting menu option in the dining area.  The dishes on the tasting menu were only so-so, definitely not worth $78 per person.  It was pretty disappointing.  The best dish was the ramen but does not make up for all the other dishes.
author: Kennedy T.

description: tasted 6 different wines. all of them tasted like vinegar. so I ordered popcorn. stale. for me? a big no.
author: linda b.

description: Just stopped in here for something different. What a great experience! Great selection of Saki and the chef's sample menu was great.
author: Tom Z.

description: Sad to say this place was a huge disappointment. While the beer is delicious, my entire table noticed glaring missteps across the food side. Chewy wagyu and overcooked noodles were some of the largest issues. I'm hopeful this experience can be chalked up to soft-opening but probably won't go back to confirm. Save some money and buy the beer at Costco.
author: E. R.

description:
Went for the soft opening, so I guess I should leave a review. A party of 4 went for the tasting menu ($68), each couple shared a beer and sake pairing ($30), which was two small pours of beer and one small pour of sake, plus your choice of full-size drink at the end, so not a bad deal, but not a different drink for each course like you might expect with other tasting menus.

4 stars for the food. Highlights for me were the burrata, tongue, and tantanmen. Only one dish really missed, the oxtail soup, which was bland and under-seasoned.

2 stars for the service. The weirdest thing that happened was during the dessert course, where I was excited to find lemon curd underneath the panna cotta. I pointed it out to the people I was eating with and they said "What?". They didn't have any (my wife may have had a small bit, but the others didn't). A waitress noticed us inspecting our desserts so asked if anything was missing, so we told her. She came back five minutes later and said that the chef admitted that he forgot to put the lemon curd in two of ours, but asked if we enjoyed it anyway (which we said yes, because we're polite, I guess). So we sat and finished our meal, expecting something to come out as an apology -- maybe a replacement dessert, or a comp or something else since we missed out on one of three ingredients in the dessert, but nothing happened. Kinda a bummer when you're spending $100/person to have the kitchen admit to a mistake and not try to make it right. Other weirdness can be chalked up to the soft opening, like the waitress not really being sure of what was in each dish when describing them, and the hostess completely ignoring us when we walked out (I said my traditional "Thanks" on the way out and was met with nothing, even though there were only about 8 people in the restaurant at that point).

Hopefully they can work out those kinks but food overall was pretty tasty.
author: Ned F.

description: This is the worst $$$$ experience I ever had! Heard about this place since the soft opening. As an enthusiastic lover of Japanese food, my SO and I were really looking fwd to this. We tried the set menu of 7 dishes. Every single one of them was a weird combo of food. Don't take me wrong, i have tried many Michelin restaurant and am adventurous with food combo. But every disc we had here was like : it would have so much better without food xyz... also, there was no wagyu steak in the set Menu, just different part of the beef, but no steak in the traditional steakhouse grill way. All the beef parts we had was not impressive either. There are half of the dishes that made me feel: hey I can cook better than this !
author: Lily S.

description: Beautifully complex flavors. We did the tasting menu. Favorite courses were the tataki and the ramen. The tataki with smoked tosazu, eggplant and chive is genius. The vinegar sauce has been transformed into a gelatin making it easy to pile onto the beef and potato. Savory, salty, tangy. Delicious. Desserts also did not disappoint.
author: L C.

description: We got the tasting menu with beer pairing and loved each course. The ramen was especially good. Highly recommend.
author: Alex N.

description: Delicious beer, delicious food. Beautiful ambiance. I had a wonderful time going to Hitachino. I'm not super familiar with Wagyu, and thought this was a delightful introduction to the special kind of beef. Thank you Chef Nori for your thought and work on this beautiful spot!
author: m p.

description: Great place for beers and food!  Great service and super clean and new.  Not sure why this place only have 3 stars.  Good music too!
author: Patrick L.

description: Came here on a busy Saturday on a whim with my wife. We were intrigued by the tasting menu and especially the dessert with Wagyu beef in it!! I'm happy to say that, even after reading some of these reviews, we had a fantastic time! All around everything from the service to the food was awesome. We didn't get to sit in the dining room because we didn't have a reservation so we had the a la carte menu, the tantanmen, Wagyu tongue skewers, and the Wagyu dessert, o the Wagyu dessert! Were definitely some of the highlights! Very happy and we will be back just for the dessert. Also on a side note, the beer of course is amazing but most people know Hitachino's beer reputation, but the bartender let us try some of the sakes on the house and even that was amazing! They have a sparkling sake on tap, and a brown sake that is made with brown rice, WOW! Will definitely get some sake next time around as well!
author: Kalvin M.
